computers & electronicsThis Week's Highlights: 
How Geocaching WorksHow GPS Works
How Wireless Power Works
How Municipal WiFi WorksHow Electric Motors Work

 
Is it better to turn my computer off when I am not using it or leave it on all 
the time?  This is one of those questions where there is no single right answer. In other 
words, it depends on how you use your computer. Read why shutting it off when not being used could save you money.    This week's trivia question:How many GPS satellites are in the Earth's orbit? 
Find out   
 
How Geocaching Works - Thousands of people around the world use their GPS receivers to geocache, or seek out treasures hidden by other players while checking out interesting locations. Explore the history of geocaching and learn how to find and place geocaches of your own.   
   This week's video:How GPS Works
 - Have you ever wondered how a global positioning system receiver can pinpoint your location? As long as you have a GPS receiver and a clear view of the sky, you'll never be lost again.  See how GPS works in this HowStuffWorks video. 
     Also at HowStuffWorks:
 
How Municipal WiFi Works - Learn about the amazing things that these networks can do -- besides potentially providing free or cheap Internet access, about the technology behind them and why "Municipal WiFi" can be a misnomer. 
 
How Wireless Power Works - Unless you are particularly organized and good with tie wrap, you probably have a few dusty power cord tangles around your home. Find out how methods of wireless power transmission could cut the clutter or lead to clean sources of electricity. 
 
How Electric Motors Work - You might be surprised to find out just how much work is done by electric motors. You'll find them in your kitchen, bathroom and office...and that's just the beginning. Learn all about makes electric motors tick.
